completion: The roof of the building was in excellent condition with interlocking concrete tiles which were intact and had no gaps or missing tiles.
There were no gaps under tiles, and so no Potential Roost Features (PRFs) were present (see Plate 4)..
The ridge tiles and mortar were intact with no gaps, offering no PRFs (see Plate 5)..
Fascia boards were tight to the walls and had guttering attached with no gaps and no potential roost features were present (see Plate 6)..
Window and door frames were in good condition with no access to the internal spaces and offered no PRFs (see Plate 7)..
The flashing around the dormers and between the steep pitched roof and side of the house were well fitted and in good condition with no gaps for roosting (see Plate 8)..
The rough bricks provide an ideal substrate for bat droppings to adhere to and these would have been easily visible, but no evidence was found (see Plate 9).
The cladding on the rear and east sides of the house were intact with no gaps and no PRFs present (Plate 10)..

A thorough and comprehensive search of the ground and flat surfaces around the building (including the garage roof and tops of dormers) found no evidence of bat activity such as discarded prey items or droppings (Plate 11)..
The membrane and timber support structures were all exposed and visible with no potential roost features (see Plate 13)..
The membrane and timber structures (rafters, purlins, etc.) were all intact and in good condition with no apparent gaps and no PRFs (see Plate 14)..
There were no obvious access points into the internal garage space and there was no evidence of bat activity or presence (e.g.
droppings or discarded prey items; see Plate 16)..
No potential roost features or evidence of bat activity or presence were identified, and the building was considered to have negligible bat roosting potential..
The building was occupied and in very good condition with no significant structural issues such as cracks in the walls and gaps in the roof..

The garage pitched roof was in excellent weather-tight condition and was constructed of overlapping tiles (see Plate 2), the method of construction meant that these tightly interlocking tiles had no gaps between them (see Plate 3).
Inspection found no gaps beneath ridge on the hipped roof of the garage or its roof tiles and it was clear that there were no Potential Roost Features (PRFs).
It was concluded that the main body of the garage roof offered no roosting potential.
The flashings around the garage roof and the main body of the house were well sealed with no PRFs and offered no roosting potential (See Plate 4)..
The soffits and eaves of the garage were also found to be well sealed with no gaps or spaces that would offer roosting opportunities (see Plate 5).
Again, this was found to be of the same construction as the garage, and it offered no PRFs(see Plate 6)..
The window and door frames were well sealed and offered no roosting potential (see Plate 7)..
The walls were intact and had no PRFs or gaps; these had no roosting potential or access to the internal spaces.
Finally, the flat surfaces such as paving slabs around the building were thoroughly and systematically searched for evidence of bat activity and no evidence of bats was present..
The house has a pitched hip roof with slate tiles and rear and front facing dormers (Plate 1, Plate 2).
The conservatory has no bat potential.
There are no gaps or crevices, so no potential roost features (PRFs) were present (see Plate 3).
There were no gaps under the slates, so no potential roost features present.
The flashing between the single storey pitched roof and side of the house was well fitted with no gaps, no PRFs present (Plate 4)..
There were small gaps under some of the ridge tiles towards the gable end of the single storey pitched roof which might be suitable for bats.
Roosting potential was considered borderline.
The main hipped roof was in good condition.
Slates were tight fitting with no gaps, and the roof had some moss coverage which prevent bats from having any access.
No evidence of potential roost features was identified (see Plate 7)..
Small gaps were apparent under some of hip ridge tiles relatively near to where the proposed dormer will be installed.
Bat roosting potential considered borderline (see Plate 8)..
Roosting potential considered negligible (see Plate 9 and Plate 10)..
The inside of some of the internal loft space was lined with a membrane which had no gaps and would prevent bats from entering the internal space (see Plate 11)..

A thorough and systematic search of all the flat surfaces and grounds within the internal spaces were searched to look for evidence of current or historic bat use and activity (e.g., droppings, discarded prey items) and none were found (Plate 12).

A thorough inspection of the timbers which were exposed showed no signs of bat activity such as scratch marks, staining or droppings and there were no obvious access points into the internal spaces (Plate 13)..
Occupied areas of the second-floor internal spaces were boarded and plastered, offering no access into the building, and showing no evidence of bat activity or presence.
Windows were well sealed with no gaps and no access points into the building.
No potential roost features present (Plate 14)..
Although minor potential roost features were identified, there was a lack of overall suitability of the roof spaces and a lack of evidence of bat activity or presence.
Roosting potential was therefore considered negligible..
The building had a slate roof which was in relatively good condition for the most part, with relatively few slipped or slightly lifted slates (see Plate 1 to Plate 4).
These could conceivably provide access to bats.
The key features however, on this roof comprise the purposely placed ventilation gaps underneath raised tiles along the ridges (see Plate 3, Plate 5 and Plate 6).
There was a clear gap here as the boarding did not sit flush against the stone.
Much of the pointing amongst the external stones was in good order offering limited possible roost spaces here.
However, there were some ventilation holes located within the walls, which in theory could allow access for bats (see Plate 1, Plate 2 and Plate 8).
Thorough inspection of the external features identified no bat droppings, or other such signs were identified anywhere around the building at all.

To summarise, the building had numerous potential bat access points: beneath some lifted slates on the roof, especially those along the ridges for ventilation, and within the eaves of all along the building on the northern and southern aspects.
No signs of bat activity were identified anywhere around the building.

This was confirmed by the presence of a small concentrated scattering of bat droppings underneath the ridge clearly showing a place where small numbers of bats have previously roosted (see Plate 10 and Plate 11).
Similarly, no signs of bat activity could be seen anywhere here.
One potential roost feature (PRF) was identified on this side of the property which comprised the end roof capping and a gap between the capping and the stone wall (see Plate 4).
All doors and windows on this southern section of the building were fully sealed preventing any realistic access to the inside of the property here (see Plate 5 and Plate 6).
An inspection of the corrugated roof revealed a lack of suitability for bats due to a complete lack of access points (see Plate 7).
The eaves of the building were also completely sealed (see Plate 8).
It was therefore considered that the only area of potential access around the roof comprised the end capping on the gable ends of the southern extension (see Plate 1 to Plate 4).
The middle section and the northern extension of the building both had very clear and open access for bats to the inside in the form of open windows (see Plate 2).
However, the middle section of the building comprised traditional stone with gaps and missing pointing in the walls leading into PRFs (see Plate 10 and Plate 11).
Both of these sections of the building also had corrugated single skin rooftops which typically do not retain PRFs (see Plate 2).
To summarise, the building had a number of potential bat access points.

These comprised access to crevices underneath the end capping on the second floor gable ends, missing pointing in the middle section walls allowing access to PRFs inside these walls, and finally, free access to the inside of the middle and northern extensions of the building through large open windows.
However, despite this a loose scattering of around half a dozen droppings were identified on the floor in this room (see Plate 15).
The narrow entrance and stairs were searched for signs of bat droppings however none were found.
This comprised a small collection of droppings inside the southern part of the building on the ground floor.
The brick-built walls provide an ideal substate for bat activity to adhere to (e.g., droppings, discarded prey items), but no evidence was found (see Plate 6)..
Windows and doors were in good condition with no access to the internal spaces and offered no potential roost features (PRFs).
The roofs on top of the bay windows were in good condition with no gaps or missing tiles.
Flashing between the tiles and the brick walls were well sealed and offered no PRFs (Plate 7)..
Small gaps were apparent in gaps in the mortar along the verges of the lean-to roof above the utility room.
These gaps are large enough for bats and offer access into the internal loft space.
Roosting potential borderline (Plate 8)..
A thorough and comprehensive search of the ground and flat surfaces around the building found no evidence of bat activity (e.g., discarded prey items, droppings) or presence (Plate 9)..
The main house internal roof space had exposed timbers which were in good condition and showed no signs of bat presence or activity (e.g., staining, droppings, or discarded prey).
In addition, some light penetration into the loft around the eaves showed that there were some potential gaps into the loft space.

The remainder of the lofts’ flat surfaces and floors within the internal void were thoroughly searched for signs of bat activity (e.g., discarded prey items, droppings) and no evidence was found (Plate 12)..
The rough surfaces can provide an ideal substrate for bat activity (e.g., droppings, discarded prey) to adhere to.
These were all thoroughly searched but no evidence was found (Plate 13)..
The gable end blockwork was well mortared and had no gaps between the blockwork and the roof pitch.
It was concluded that this area offered no potential for bats to gain access into the loft space (Plate 14)..
The roof was in good condition and had tightly interlocking slates and negligible possibility for bats was present around any flashings or fascias and soffits.
Small gaps were identified under the tiles along the roof verge but a close-up thorough inspection from inside the loft found no evidence of bat activity or presence.
No other potential roost features were identified.
Therefore, overall the building was considered to have negligible bat roosting potential..
The pitched roof of the residential property was in very good condition, with very tight tiles and no cracked or missing tiles (See Plate 1).
The brickwork of the chimney appeared in good condition and offered no PRFs (See Plate 3).
The redbrick walls of the building were in good condition, with no gaps in the mortar or cracks in the walls offering no PRFs (See Plate 4).
The gable wall brickwork and bargeboards appeared in good condition with no gaps or cracks offering no PRFs (See Plate 5)..
The building eaves were well sealed and offered no PRFs (See Plate 6).
The doors and the windows of the residential property all appeared well sealed, with no gaps or PRFs identified (See Plate 7).
The dormer roof and windows were in good condition with no gaps in tiles or cracks, with the flashing appearing well sealed offering no PRFs (See Plate 8)..
The flat roof of the conservatory was in good condition and offered no PRFs (See Plate 8).
However, no evidence of bat activity was found at the site.
The internal loft was generally well-sealed, with roof underfelt membrane and wooden beams appearing to be in good condition and offering no PRFs (See Plate 9).
No staining or other evidence of bats was found in these areas..
The concrete shed was in relatively good condition, however the internal space was easily accessible to bats due to the gaps at the top of the walls (See Plate 13).
The doors and windows of the outbuilding were generally in good condition and reasonably well sealed, however some gaps did exist above the door frame.
The doors and walls of the outbuilding were in relatively good condition, and were thoroughly searched for evidence of bat activity, however no evidence was found..
No PRFs were identified in the various structures.
The survey of the site also showed no evidence of bat activity, clearly showing that bats had not been using the site.
The flat roofs were in generally satisfactory condition with no gaps present.
Small gaps in the mortar between the coping stones were noted (see Plate 4), these were examined and found to offer no roosting potential..
The external walls generally intact with no missing or cracked mortar in the apparent (see Plate 10).
The tiles on the east facing aspect were equally well mortared and offered no roosting opportunities (see Plate 11)..
The window and door frames, including the roller doors, were intact and had no PRFs and no significant roosting potential (see Plate 12 and Plate 13)..
There were no apparent roost features or access for bats to the internal space.
No PRFs were identified across the building.
No evidence of bat activity was found externally or internally..

The pitched and hipped roof was in generally satisfactory condition with no apparent gaps under ridge tiles (see Plate 3) or slipped, cracked or missing roof tiles (see Plate 4) or other Potential Roost Features (PRFs) or significant opportunities for roosting or access to the internal space..
The flat roof areas to the rear of the property were generally intact with no roosting potential and no access for bats to the internal spaces (see Plate 5)..
The external walls generally intact (see Plate 8) although a number of cracks and missing mortar in the pointing were apparent (see Plate 9).
The window and door frames were intact and had no PRFs and no roosting potential (see Plate 10)..
No PRFs were identified across the building and no evidence of bat activity was found within either building..
All buildings had pitched roofs of overlapping slate tiles.
All buildings were considered to have at least some potential for roosting bats.
The building had pitched roof with modern interlocked tiles offering no Potential Roost Feature (PRFs) for bats (see Plate 3 and Plate 4).
No signs of bat activity were seen to be present.
All windows and doors were similarly well sealed (see Plate 9) and walls had pointing in good condition with no suitable gaps for roosting bats (see Plate 10).
No signs of bat activity were seen to be present on any surfaces around the building..
No signs of bat activity were seen anywhere.
Based on a full search around the inside of the property, a lack of signs and suitable roosting locations, it was considered that the building had negligible bat roosting potential.
The building comprised a traditional stone walled structure with a pitched stone tiled and slate roof (see Plate 1 - Plate 3).
The walls on this structure were not sealed at all.
There was extensive pointing missing around the stones (see Plate 4 and Plate 5).
In addition, there were clear ventilation holes in the walls which opened up the possibility of bats flying directly into the structure and roosting inside.
This clearly resulted in many potential roost features inside the walls themselves all around the building.
The roof of the building also had numerous crevices underneath slates and stones (see Plate 9), as well as clear gaps leading directly into the building itself..
To summarise, the building had a number of potential bat access points.

These comprised extensive numbers of crevices within the outer walls where pointing was missing in between stones, in the verges of the building, and in the roof of the building where stones/slates were lifted, slipped or missing.
Despite the fact that bats could, in theory, gain access into all aspects of the building, no bats or signs were seen anywhere around the inside the lean tos.
It was clear to see that bats could conceivably gain access to the inside of the building.
The roof ridge was well sealed with no gaps beneath the ridge tiles and no PRFs or roosting potential (see Plate 3).
No missing mortar or gaps under the gable end ridge tiles was present..

The roof pitches were in good condition with no apparent gaps, slipped cracked or missing tiles (see Plate 4) or other Potential Roost Features (PRFs) or significant opportunities for roosting or access to the internal space; a light moss covering across the north facing pitch effectively sealed any potential gaps.
The external walls were intact with no missing or cracked mortar apparent and offered no roosting opportunities (see Plate 8)..
The window and door frames were intact and had no PRFs or roosting potential (see Plate 9)..
No significant PRFs were identified across the inside of the loft space and no evidence of bat activity was found externally or internally..
Elsewhere on the building, the eaves were tightly sealed against the stonework and plaster rendering (see Plate 5).
All windows and doors to the building were also in good condition..
The roof comprised of interlocking tiles, which were generally well fitted (see Plate 6).
However, some gaps were present along the roof where the tiles were uneven and lifted (see Plate 7).
Overall, despite a thorough search no evidence of bats was found on the exterior of the building.
It was therefore concluded that no bats could roost within this roof due to a complete lack of access points, and therefore no PRFs..
The building had a slate roof which was in relatively good condition for the most part (see Plate 3), with relatively few slipped or slightly lifted slate.
The ridge tiles did however have some areas of missing pointing underneath which could conceivably offer potential access to a possible roost space (see Plate 4).
All textured outer walls of the building were sealed and in good condition (see Plate 8).
The windows and doors were not compromised in anyway and were completely sealed preventing any bat access (see Plate 9 to Plate 11).
One single bat dropping was identified on the northern elevation (see Plate 13), however, no clear PRF was identified in the immediate vicinity of this evidence.
The building had a slate roof which was in relatively good condition for the most part, with relatively few slipped or slightly lifted slates (see Plate 1 and Plate 2).
These could conceivably provide access to bats.
There was a clear gap here as the boarding did not sit flush against the stone (see Plate 4).
Much of the pointing amongst the external stone walls was in good order offering no possible roost spaces here.
All windows and doors were sealed around the outside of the building.
Thorough inspection of the external features identified no bat droppings, or other such signs were identified anywhere around the building at all.
However, it was considered that there were potential bat roosts underneath the slates and atop the walls..
No evidence was recorded anywhere inside or outside of the buildings.
The roof was in good condition and was constructed from overlapping tiles.
Close inspection showed that there were no gaps under ridge tiles or overlapping tiles.
It was concluded that the main body of the roof offered no bat roosting potential (see Plate 2)..
The roof edges, these were found to be intact and well mortared and no gaps were noted.
The window and door frames were found to be intact and well-fitted.
It was found that there were no gaps and none of the windows or doors offered any roosting potential (see Plate 5).
Garage 2 was a stone and brick-built structure with a flat concrete roof to the front and pitched tiled roof to the rear.
Although generally intact, there were significant gaps throughout the building..
The single slab roof at the front of the garage was intact but there were gaps around the slab that offered roosting potential and access to the internal space of the garage (see Plate 13)..
To the rear of the garage, the pitched roof had numerous gaps beneath the overlapping tiles that offered significant roosting opportunities (see Plate 14)..
The walls of Garage 2 were generally intact although there were numerous gaps between bricks and stones where the mortar was missing (see Plate 15).
However, no evidence of current or historic bat use was found..
The stone shed was a small structure with a pitched roof of slate tiles..

Externally, the roof was found to be intact (see Plate 19) although there were gaps beneath tiles on the southern pitch which offered roosting potential and access to the internal space (see Plate 20)..
Numerous gaps were noted in the verges and the stonework on the shed (see Plate 20) that offered roosting potential and access to the internal space..
The stone frame of the door was in fair condition but gaps around the door itself offered access to the internal space (see Plate 20)..
They were constructed from red brick with overlapping tile on pitched roofs.
The roofs were pitched and of overlapping asbestos cement tiles.

These were generally heavily cobwebbed although they offered some bat roost potential..

The general condition of the building was good with no missing bricks or cracks in the sandstone or timber.

droppings, staining etc.) were found.

The barns were brick-built structures, with pitched roof covered with corrugated sheets..
Both barns were in reasonable condition although gaps and holes in the brickwork were apparent.
The roofs were in fair condition and constructed from corrugated sheets throughout..
Whilst the roofs were generally intact, gaps under the corrugated roof edges were apparent, these offered roosting potential and access to the internal voids.
There was unrestricted access to the internal space in Barn 2 via the open entrance and the wooden slatted walls (see Plate 4)..
Gaps around the sliding door frames and an open pane-less windows of Barn 1 would have offered access to the internal space and roosting potential (see Plate 5)..
Finally the flat surfaces around the building were thoroughly and systematically searched for evidence of bat activity, but none was found (See Plate 7)..
A number of bat droppings were found (see Plate 11).
Evidence of bat use, in the form of droppings, was found externally.
The farmhouse was in good condition with no significant structural issues such as cracks in the walls and gaps in the roof..
The multi-pitched roof was in good condition and was constructed from a mix of overlapping cement (see Plate 2) and slate tiles and corrugated sheets.
Here, inspection found that there were gaps under the overlapping tiles (see Plate 3) but the corrugated sheets were intact.
It was concluded that the main body of the roof offered roosting potential and access to the internal storage spaces at the rear of the property..
Gaps under the corrugated roof edges of the large storage areas to the rear were apparent, these offered roosting potential and further access to the internal voids (see Plate 13)..
The walls and flat surfaces around the building were thoroughly and systematically searched for evidence of bat activity and no evidence of bat activity was found.

In summary, the Farmhouse had a number of Potential Roost Features in the form of gaps beneath the tiles and in the verges as well as gaps in the mortar of the internal walls of the large storage space.
Evidence of bat use, in the form of droppings, was found internally.
The Barn was a brick-built structure, with pitched roof of slate tiles and corrugated sheets..
The Barn was in reasonable condition with some minor structural issues that included cracks in the walls and gaps in the roof..
The roof was in fair condition and was constructed from overlapping tiles (to the south pitch) and corrugated sheets (on the northern pitch).
Close inspection found that there were some gaps under the ridge and overlapping tiles (see Plate 2) but the corrugated sheets were intact.
It was concluded that the main body of the roof offered roosting potential and access to the internal space of the Barn..
Gaps under the corrugated roof edges were apparent, these offered roosting potential and further access to the internal voids.

The walls were generally intact although putlock/ventilation holes and cracks were apparent, in both the north and south facing aspects of the building, that offered roosting potential (see Plate 4)..
The walls and flat surfaces around the building were thoroughly and systematically searched for evidence of bat activity and a dropping was found on the north facing aspect..
A number of individual bat droppings were found (see Plate 13), particularly in the western room where there was a missing window pane (see Plate 2)..

In summary, The Barn had a number of Potential Roost Features in the form of gaps beneath the tiles and between the brickwork of the building and it was considered to provide moderate opportunity for roosting bats.
Evidence of bat use, in the form of droppings, was found externally and internally.
The roof of overlapping sheets was generally intact although gaps under the ridge line and large holes were apparent (see Plate 5).
It was clear that bats might conceivably be able to enter the building via these routes..
The external walls were intact with no opportunities for bats to access the internal spaces of the building (see Plate 5)..
Overall it was concluded that the building had negligible roosting potential..
It was concluded that bats were not roosting in the building and no further surveys were required..
The pitched roof of the main house was constructed from interlocking roofing stone roofing tiles and was intact with no missing, slipped or cracked tiles (See Plate 3).

The roof of the cottages was similarly constructed from stone tiles and thisbut was in a poor state of repair with numerous holes and gaps throughout – a portion of the rear pitch had partially collapsed (See Plate 3)..
The roof verges of the disused cottage gable had numerous gaps in the pointing allowing access to Potential Roost Features (PRFs) the internal space (see Plate 5)..
Therefore any impact would be classed as ‘negligible’..
The pitched roof of the property was in good condition and intact, despite a light moss covering.
The tiles overlapped with no gaps or slipped tiles, offering no Potential Roost Features (PRFs) and showed no evidence of bat activity (See Plate 2).
No potential roost features were identified, and no signs of bat activity were found.
The house was in good condition with no significant structural issues such as cracks in the walls and gaps in the roof..
The pitched roof was in good condition and was constructed from overlapping cement tiles (see Plate 2).
It was concluded that the main body of the roof offered roosting potential and access to the internal spaces of the property..
The window and door frames were found to be intact and well-fitted (see Plate 7) and offered no opportunities for roosting..

The walls and flat surfaces around the building were thoroughly and systematically searched for evidence of bat activity; the rough surfaces provided an excellent substrate for droppings to adhere to and these would have easily been observed, however no signs of bats were discovered..
However, no evidence of bat activity was found externally or internally.
The buildings were variously of corrugated sheeting, brick, blockwork and wood, with pitched roofs of tiles, wood or corrugated sheets.
The condition of the wooden buildings was generally poor although the more substantial block work buildings were generally more intact.
The roofs of many of the buildings were intact (see Plate 2); these were almost entirely of corrugated sheets.
The corrugated sheet roofing offered no Potential Roost Features (PRFs).
Building 2 had a slate roof but the gaps between the slates were so small that it was considered to offer no roosting opportunities (see Plate 3)..
However, the wooden sheds to the south of the Site were in poor condition (see Plate 5)..
Entry for bats to potentially roosts would have bene readily possible through many opening and gaps.
No evidence for the use of the Site by bats was found in any of the buildings..
The roof of the house was in excellent condition, it had overlapping tiles which were intact and there were no slipped or missing tiles.
The ridge tiles were tightly fitted and there were no gaps under tiles so no Potential Roost Features (PRfs) were present (see Plate 2)..
The windows and doors were very well sealed with no gaps around the frames and offered no roosting opportunities.
Similarly, the walls were intact with no opportunities for bats to access the internal spaces of the building (see Plate 8)..
Their rough finish was an ideal substrate for droppings to adhere to and these would have been easily visible, but there were no suitable PRFs and no evidence of bats was found..
A thorough and comprehensive search of the ground and flat surfaces around the building found no evidence of bat activity (see Plate 9)..
Despite a thorough search externally and internally, no evidence of bat activity was found.
The roofs were pitched and the covering was of interlocking concrete tiles throughout.
The walls, of red brick topped with sandstone blocks, were in good condition although there were a number of gaps in the pointing (see Plate 6).
In summary, the buildings had no obvious Potential Roost Features, and no signs of bat activity were observed around the exterior of the building.
The inspection began by checking the exterior of the building for signs of bats such as droppings, however none were discovered.
The roof of the property was pitched with tiles that were in good order and with no suitable gaps that could facilitate bat access (see Plate 5).
